The more traditional has no place in this library.
The glass and chrome building is flooded with light.

For weeks on end, professional movers swarmed over the entire collection of San Francisco's 80-year-old main library.
A million books were on these shelves, some well-thrumped, some gathering dust for years.
The collection, while large, had been disarray for decades.
Books had disappeared.
Others had been thrown away.
Now, at last, the library was on the verge of a new era.
When the movers were finished in early spring, they had transferred every book across Fulton Street to new shelves in a breathtakingly new building.
The distance is short, but the journey is... They just said that they put all one million books in the new library.
I heard a figure of three million, though, at a previous tape.
That's in the whole system.
But in the new Maine, they said they moved all one million books from the old Maine to the new Maine.
There are 37,000 short.
An often neglected library into a marvel for the 21st century.
San Francisco has gone in 10 years from a neglected system to a cutting-edge system in the center.
This building is a bridge from the past to the future.
I don't think there's anyone who got there where they are in life without having to leave a public library.
San Francisco will begin the millennium in the midst of a cultural and civic renaissance.
Visual evidence is all around.
The New Museum of Modern Art dominates the South of Market skyline.
Just across Third Street, a recently opened view of Buena Gardens provides calm and culture against the glorious backdrop of the city.
The Palace of the Legion of Honor has been renovated and included in growing crowds.
And the DeYoung Museum in Golden Gate Park is due for major reconstruction.
City Hall is getting the treatment too following the 1989 earthquake.
The jewel in the crown completing the grand plan for the Civic Center is the building just finished at this site.
The new main library.
In four years it went up and in these images it looks so easy.
But getting to this point was fraught with politics, cultural jealousy, indifference, benign neglect, and incredible determination by a few people that overcame all that.
Fundraisers, activists, architects, librarians, and donors.
The champions were not the politicians who never were quite sure what to do about the library.
It's an intriguing story how this library came to be.
The public library had always been an orphan in the cultural household of San Francisco.
The sophisticated and the well-to-do in this city were generous to the opera, the symphony, and the ballet.
The principal constituency of the public library came from a far different, less affluent strata of society.
Surprisingly, it was a powerful group, able to generate the support that made this building possible.
It included people like Jade Snow Wong,
who long before she became a ceramicist, was the best-selling fifth Chinese daughter.
She grew up poor in Chinatown.
Around 11 years old, I started going to the library.

I never was allowed outside of Chinatown, but going to the library was okay, and I would take out four books every day, meaning I would buy four books, and I would eat a book a day and go back the fifth day and get four more books.
I think I was fascinated because through the books I learned about all the big world outside of San Antonio and the world of mixed views.
Wong and people with similar experiences became the grassroots from which the new library grew.
I don't know.
It's to me the frontier of democracy.
A few libraries.
Everybody, no matter how poor, they have.
But the story of San Francisco's library begins long before Wong's early memory.
Even in its wild gold rush days, San Francisco was a literary town.
The first public library borrowed or rented space for their small collection.
The library, like the city, was on the move.
In 1898, it took over a wing of the new city hall.
In April 1906, earthquake and fire.
I love this stuff.
The city hall was severely damaged by the earthquake.
It took a while for the fire to get to the library.
And once it did, it burned virtually everything that was in the library.
Peter Booth Wiley has written a history of the library and the city.
But from the ashes, the new city grew, determined to enhance its prominence as a cultural center of the West.

in a reborn civic center near the new city hall.

But for all its collections and affection, there was plenty wrong with what they called the Old Man.

The new librarians stopped that.
They're not buying any books.
Librarian Ken Dowling found when he came to work.
It was quite embarrassing to be a person with two master's degrees and a 30-year library director, and I couldn't find a book in the Old Main Library because of the way it was organized and laid out.
Mr. Dowling, because of that, decided to create his own filing system.
He did away with the Dewey Decimal System and he created something called Leveled Access, which was to jam everything together so that he had fewer categories to bother with.
It created a massive, massive nightmare, which they are now trying to unravel.
Both funds to even care for the facility, the lighting in there apparently was extremely dark, and the walls were unpainted and very dreary, and the place had a feeling of abandonment about it.
The library was an embarrassment to the city that prided itself on culture.
In the 1950s, the Chronicle ran an expose on the disgraceful condition, written by Hale Chandler.
In San Francisco, there was a feeling of frustration.
Politicians didn't allocate enough money to buy books, catalog them quickly, and hire trained professional librarians to manage the system.
And the library couldn't compete with music and arts for private funds.
Over the next 40 years,
succession of librarians and their supporters tried to bring order to the chaos.
Kevin Starr marched with costumed Minutemen to draw up support for more funds.
But politicians, perennially faced with budget shortfalls, saw the library as vulnerable.

So the library community throughout the state began to develop its political expertise, began to learn to lobby, began to learn to get its message out to the community, and that made it much more difficult for an elected official, for a mayor, to come in and to arbitrarily cut a budget.
The library had developed a constituency of its own.
Among the devotees were people like Dorothy Bryant,
who grew up in a poor Italian-American family in the Mission District and later became a best-selling novel.
It was the 30s.

There were no books.

kept everything still, and they were all lost.

The branches in the residential neighborhood still evoke the most loyalty.
They have become like the distance they are in centers of ethnic diversity.
First stop for immigrants trying to maintain their own cultures and learn a new one.
Many of the city's new residents seek out books in their native languages.
The branches supply them and try to cater... Not anymore.
This year, just for your own information, you should know, no foreign language books have been purchased.
So everything about that... You don't know...

While the 26 branches tried with rather skimpy collections to meet the needs of the neighborhood, the main library remained the brains of the system, backing up the branches, directing them, and setting the tone.
It was the main that guarded the valuable collection, like the music room's incredible treasure trove of sheet music, part of America's pop culture.
But even the five collections could erase the fact that the main library was in bad shape and was ignored in first aid.
That was evident to San Francisco philanthropist Marjorie Stern and her fellow fundraisers, Margaret Mayer and Mary Louise Stonk.

friends with many of the city's wealthy and powerful, decided to lead the fight to build a new library, a great library.

The San Francisco Public Library would proceed primarily as a municipal service rather than a cultural institution.

with all these different groups and everyone's colliding and then seeing where they're there.

Tough negotiations by Stern and her friends ensured that the library won back dollars.
Once cleared, the site for the new library oozed history.
Archaeologists pored over what had been the ceremonial heart of the city in the last century.
They found evidence of the cemetery that was here before 1870.
and the old city hall and jail, which perished in the earthquake and fire.
Building a library here required a lot of money, and getting a bond issue about was a big hurdle.
Even librarian Kevin Starr felt there wasn't enough public or political support.
